issues.description: The problem statement specifies that fix_add takes three arguments (a destination register, first operand, second operand), but both the template and solution implementations of fix_add_asm actually expect four 32-bit arguments (two 64-bit operands passed as low/high words) and return the 64-bit result in EAX:EDX rather than writing to a specified register. This mismatch in the number and meaning of parameters will confuse students when trying to invoke or implement the function.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement to describe that fix_add_asm takes two 64-bit operands passed as four 32-bit pushes (low then high word for each operand) and returns the 64-bit sum in EAX (low) and EDX (high). Alternatively, adjust the template to accept a destination register and three arguments if that was the original intent.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to the function as `fix_add`, but both the template and solution code use the identifier `fix_add_asm`. This discrepancy can confuse students trying to locate and implement the documented function stub.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the names by updating the problem statement to refer to `fix_add_asm` instead of `fix_add`, so students can directly match the documented function name with the provided stub.
